title: Weighted Job Scheduling Algorithm can also be denoted as Weighted Activity Selection Algorithm.

inline_content.Text: Weighted Job Scheduling Algorithm can also be denoted as Weighted Activity Selection Algorithm.

title: The problem is, given certain jobs with their start time and end time, and a profit you make when you finish the job, what is the maximum profit you can make given no two jobs can be executed in parallel?

inline_content.Text: The problem is, given certain jobs with their start time and end time, and a profit you make when you finish the job, what is the maximum profit you can make given no two jobs can be executed in parallel?

title: This one looks like Activity Selection using Greedy Algorithm, but there’s an added twist. That is, instead of maximizing the number of jobs finished, we focus on making the maximum profit. The number of jobs performed doesn’t matter here.

inline_content.Text: This one looks like Activity Selection using Greedy Algorithm, but there’s an added twist. That is, instead of maximizing the number of jobs finished, we focus on making the maximum profit. The number of jobs performed doesn’t matter here.

title: The first thing we do is sort the jobs by their finishing time in non-decreasing order. Why do we do this? It’s because if we select a job that takes less time to finish, then we leave the most amount of time for choosing other jobs. We have:

title:
Procedure WeightedJobScheduling(Job)
sort Job according to finish time in non-decreasing order
for i -> 2 to n
    for j -> 1 to i-1
        if Job[j].finish_time <= Job[i].start_time
            if Acc_Prof[j] + Profit[i] > Acc_Prof[i]
                Acc_Prof[i] = Acc_Prof[j] + Profit[i]
            endif
        endif
    endfor
endfor

maxProfit = 0
for i -> 1 to n
    if maxProfit < Acc_Prof[i]
        maxProfit = Acc_Prof[i]
return maxProfit

content_resolved.code:
Procedure WeightedJobScheduling(Job)
sort Job according to finish time in non-decreasing order
for i -> 2 to n
    for j -> 1 to i-1
        if Job[j].finish_time <= Job[i].start_time
            if Acc_Prof[j] + Profit[i] > Acc_Prof[i]
                Acc_Prof[i] = Acc_Prof[j] + Profit[i]
            endif
        endif
    endfor
endfor

maxProfit = 0
for i -> 1 to n
    if maxProfit < Acc_Prof[i]
        maxProfit = Acc_Prof[i]
return maxProfit

title:
Procedure FindingPerformedJobs(Job, Acc_Prof, maxProfit):
S = stack()
for i -> n down to 0 and maxProfit > 0
    if maxProfit is equal to Acc_Prof[i]
        S.push(Job[i].name
        maxProfit = maxProfit - Job[i].profit
    endif
endfor

        maxProfit = maxProfit - Job[i].profit
    endif
endfor

title: One thing to remember, if there are multiple job schedules that can give us maximum profit, we can only find one job schedule via this procedure.

inline_content.Text: One thing to remember, if there are multiple job schedules that can give us maximum profit, we can only find one job schedule via this procedure.
